comments.commentBody: Ummm...it was Mr. Brown who decided to attack the officer in his vehicle.

Thank you for your reply, and your reply to others.  Obviously I did not go through all of  the other comments; perhaps I should have.  I would think that the authors of the article would be obligated to  make a correction and address the misapprehension, as you suggest.  It does change the basic understanding of the event.

I agree, and when you add this to a standard that says the police only have to feel threatened, incidents like this happened. Mr. Willson had a black bogeyman in his mind. He's not a person to police a community like Ferguson.
Hopefully Wilson will never have a normal life.
Ummm, no...they had a ton of phorensic evidence at the scene.  When the eyewitness accounts don't match the phorensics, it calls into question the account.  Science is involved.
Proves nothing in this instance.

Darren Wilson told a well-rehearsed story, with all the essential elements to claim self-defense. I wonder who came up with the idea of using the "Hulk" comparison, him or his lawyer. Perhaps what he did was legal in the strictest sense of the word. It still seems he overreacted and used poor judgment. It's time we train police officers how to defuse situations and how to think of a gun as a last resort, not a first one.

Your experience has nothing to do with the issue of 200 years of slavery, another 100 years of Jim Crow segregation, and the remainder until now of hidden racism. Asians are not Black Americans, so your experience doesn't count, unless you were intered during WWII. I am a white male, born in the USA, by the way.

I have read some of Officer Wilson's account of what happened, and his error was in not calling for backup and waiting for it to arrive before confronting Michael Brown.

The officer describes himself as as 6-foot-4 and describes Brown in terms like "Hulk Hogan" and "like a demon". It sounds like he carries a preconceived mindset with him on the job.

Michael Brown was combative from the start, and Darren Wilson chose confrontation and escalation instead of forethought and discretion.

I also recommend reading Nation of Change's essay about Robert McCulloch, St. Louis County prosecutor, about his history with grand juries.

"Black Man Killed by Police? McCulloch Does It Again"
http://www.nationofchange.org/2014/11/25/black-man-killed-police-mcculloch/

The President should stay out because not all African Americans are criminals? What? The President has right to say anything unless all African Americans were criminals, otherwise shut up?

And it is exactly that they share the color of Michael Brown's skin and all the assumptions which come with that. A black man was just shot and killed in NYC for nothing.

This statement that the President can have nothing to say suggests attitudes which cast a long shadow on the rest of the statement, including the assertion that the same would have happened if Michael Brown were white.

When was the last time you heard of a white person being killed in an incident which started with walking in the street?

I am fairly certain that had Michael Brown been white he would be alive to tell his side of the storey and of course no one at all outside of his immediate family would know anything about an 'incident' on Aug 9. The kid was about to start college if that isn't a crying shame and a sin I don't know what is. There should have absolutely been a trial.

The President should keep out of this, as not all African-Americans are the same and not all African-Americans riot and burn buildings and, most certainly, not all African-Americans would rob a store, rough up the clerk, and assault a police officer, trying to take his gun away from him.

The vast majority of African-Americans have nothing in common with Michael Brown and the rioters, except for their skin color.

Best to look at it as it really was, which is neither an indictment of all African-Americans or an indictment of all police officers, as if Michael Brown was white and exhibited the same behavior, the outcome would be no different.

That said, it would be a good idea to issue all police officers tasers and helmet cameras, so the facts can speak for themselves.
It would a major step towards civilization to stop putting pistols into the hands of criminals and the mentally disturbed. Brutal and over-armed police are symptom more than a cause.
With money, you can commit crimes with no punishment--you'll never come near a poilice officer.

Actually, it would be far more suspicious if there were 8 blacks and 4 whites, and they couldn't get to 9.  Then you would have a stronger argument.  You needed 9 for an indictment, not 9 for a non-indictment.

'...pilfered cigarillos...'

If someone roughs you up and steals your purse, that would be called a 'pilfered purse' then?

Thank you for pointing this out.  At what point will the media notice these things.  People keep saying if he never robbed that store this would have never happened.  Yes it would, just another day, a different store.

Exactly-- what a great plan, construe an "all the evidence" presentation as thorough and fair, while directing your underlings to sow more confusion and bias favoring the accused. Absolutely diabolical. Oh and the fact his dad was killed by a black man has no bearing on his record huh? Right.
They know.
You forgot important facts.  The forensic evidence matches Wilson's testimony, and matches the witnesses who corroborate his story.  The evidence does not match those who gave conflicting testimony.
Exactly.

Actually, that's not true. The forensic evidence shows Brown was 150+ feet away from Wilson when he was killed - Wilson says otherwise. And the "stellar" witness whom the prosecutor favored b/c he agreed with the prosecutor changed his story - cut in half from one interview to the next the distance he was standing from the event. Why was his conflicting testimony held up to the same palpable scorn the prosecutor heaped on witnesses who didn't give the police-friendly version? Also, can someone explain to me how Wilson suffered a hard blow (producing bruises) on the side of his face that was away from the driver's side window? Did he forget to tell George S that Brown climbed inside for a few minutes?

What (according to the published proceedings) the Grand Jury heard and now the public are hearing from Mr Wilson are his one-sided version of what happened.

What we heard from Mr McCulloch, the prosecutor that was determined not to prosecute was that certain witnesses changed their story, were not reliable or were lying; of course those that testified in Mr Wilson's favor were telling the truth.

All this in secret, out of the public eye, with no rebuttal, no cross-examination, nothing. We may never know if justice was done. But we know for sure, it was not seen to be done, which is equally important.

And officer Wilson is free to do the rounds of the media, spinning himself as the 100-lb weakling against the demonic Mr Brown.

The proceedings if this Grand Jury may have been within the letter of the law, but they just didn't look like justice.

While you're right about the "athlete" comment, it says that the 15 year old (who is currently 5'10 and 140 lbs) wants to become a vegan and "practice calisthenics to get lean and fit". Presumably he doesn't see himself as "lean" at present, despite his BMI of about 20.

I certainly hope that the photo is not of the boy in question--that a parent so concerned about what his/her eats would not allow such tattoos.

At any rate, I believe that many posters are reading too much into the question here. Many healthy 15-year-old boys are around 140# at 5'10". It's also true that many are just gaining the physical maturity at that age to be able to build muscle mass, which is what I see him as wanting; his parent does not say that he wants to lose weight. And the parent is also unsure, not necessarily against the idea. The answer, that a Registered Dietitian, especially one with extra expertise in sports nutrition, can help him get the most out of a vegan diet.

And nowhere does it say he is an athlete!
You're describing a police state. I''d prefer not to live in one. I think that's why my ancestors (and maybe yours) came to this country.

I would love to be the guy arguing in favor of mercury in our air and water supply. What a job. I love the fossil fuels guy arguing that present regulations were enough, as if they had not fought against those regulations also. Industry always claims some new set of regulations will destroy it when they usually figure out a way to make more money eventually anyway. American Capitalism; smart enough to overcome any challenge except common sense regulation. Pluuuueeeeez!.

Seems like it would be fairly easy to list the actual costs of "each incremental improvement (that) comes at a significant cost to business and government." I'm sure someone has figured it out. Then we could weigh that against the lives saved and disease averted. That would be some cold calculus indeed. Beyond that, industry and their political lackeys have always had to be dragged kicking and screaming to do anything for the public good. Then often when they arrive, they end up making more money than before as new technology is created.
~~~
http://theclimateadvisor.com/

This isn't quite right. President Obama is basing these rules off of the statute, which directs the EPA to set thigs like ozone particles. That's similar to why President Bush last updated the rules in 2008.  He can't just go out and change the tax code, though.

It is truly unfortunate that industry groups can find no credible scientific evidence to support any form of regulation. It was that way when tobacco was deemed to be safe. It was that way when no one cared about drinking and driving.
The end game for the industry seems to be 'our financial interest is more important than your science.' The end game for Republicans seems to be 'all science is false, so let the free market work its magic.' We are becoming a nation that asks irrelevant questions to stop progress. We used to ask big questions so we can be at the forefront of progress.

And right on the heels of the agreement with China earlier this month. I am so proud that President Obama is leading on an issue whose importance he's addressed since 2008.  I know it's the last stretch of his term and rue to speculate he needed to wait until after the elections due to this not being a national priority.
